summary: See economic, political and markets news from across Europe as governments and financial institutions deal with the continuing debt crisis.

summary: The Rangers could only muster one goal against suddenly hot Pittsburgh.

summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Jan. 20, 2012

headline: What's News
summary: Here are today's top business stories from the Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Dow Has Blue-Chip Day
summary: Strong earnings from IBM powered blue-chip stocks even as discouraging quarterly reports from other bellwethers kept a lid on broader market gains.

headline: The Case of the Vanishing Sandwich
summary: What happened to the Eli Manning, which has disappeared from the menu at a sandwich shop in San Francisco?

headline: Probe Cites Pilot Errors in 2010 Ethiopian Airlines Crash
summary: A series of pilot mistakes marked by extreme and inconsistent flight commands caused an Ethiopian Airlines jet to crash minutes after departing Beirut in January 2010.

headline: Netflix Changes Marketing Chief
summary: Netflix said its longtime marketing chief will leave that position and assume a spot on the board, and it appointed a temporary replacement.

headline: Davos to Take Center of Corporate Stage
summary: Around 1,600 businessmen and 900 representatives of government, religion and other strands of civil society will be in the Swiss resort of Davos to try to make sense of such things as last year's upheavals in the Middle East, the euro zone crisis and Japan's storm damage.

headline: Freshman Slump
summary: The GOP freshman in Congress aren't voting like Tea Partiers.

headline: News Corp. Considers Bid for Turkish Media Group
summary: News Corp. is considering a bid for Sabah-ATV, adding a new competitor to a small handful of big western private-equity and media companies in the running to possibly buy Turkey's No. 2 media group.

headline: Disclosure Increased on Overseas Wire Transfers
summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Friday adopted a rule that will require protections for consumers that transfer money internationally, the bureau's first substantive rule since starting up as a financial-markets watchdog in July.

headline: Noonan: The No-Obama Drama
summary: The Republican campaign is compelling, but it may prove to be damaging.

headline: Matthew Kaminski: Mayor 'McSchwinn,' Loveless in Seattle
summary: An 'anti-car' crusader from the Sierra Club tests a liberal city's limits, and patience.

headline: R. Allen Stanford's Emails From Prison
summary: Mr. Stanford, accused of a $7.2 billion fraud, was severely beaten in prison in September 2009 while awaiting trial. In these emails, filed as part of the court record in the case, he told family members and his former fiancée how his perspective on life changed, as well as the effects of the beating and subsequent medication he got for his injuries.

headline: Gavilon Retains Morgan Stanley to Explore Options
summary: Gavilon, the third-largest U.S. grain trader, has hired Morgan Stanley as an adviser as it explores strategic alternatives.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's pictures, a fireman comforts a child after a school bus accident in Pennsylvania, Christians celebrate a holiday in Ethiopia, China prepares for New Year's festivities and more.

headline: Photos of the Day: Jan. 20
summary: In today's pictures, a fireman comforts a child after a school bus accident in Pennsylvania, Christians celebrate a holiday in Ethiopia, China prepares for New Year's festivities and more.

headline: Banks Seized in Florida, Georgia, Pennsylvania
summary: Regulators on Friday closed American Eagle Savings Bank in Pennsylvania, Central Florida State Bank and First State Bank in Georgia, marking the first three bank failures of 2012.

headline: Sears Shares Surge 13%
summary: Sears shares jumped 13% on Friday amid expectations the department store retailer will be able to reassure its merchandise financiers that it has the wherewithal and the desire to meet its obligations.

headline: Ships Collide in Bosporus
summary: A cargo ship collided with two other vessels at the mouth of the Bosporus strait, one of the world's busiest shipping lanes.

headline: Stock Moves Disperse as Market Correlation Eases
summary: After months of moving in near-unison, U.S. stocks are breaking away in what some analysts are calling the biggest dispersion in recent market history. At the same time, the options market is priced as though the phenomenon could be fleeting.

headline: South Carolina Town Tests Candidates
summary: Republican candidates have talked a lot about job creation ahead of the South Carolina primary. Yet none of them have spent much time courting votes in the state's most job-starved region, including the town of Dillon on the I-95 corridor.

headline: Thomson Reuters Creates Magazine for Davos Forum
summary: Thomson Reuters has created a magazine called Reuters and will distribute it at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

headline: Business Curtailed for Old Republic's Mortgage Insurer
summary: Old Republic International said its mortgage-insurance subsidiary will pay just 50% of every claim under orders from its main regulator in North Carolina.

headline: SEC Clamps Down on Secrecy in Foreign IPOs
summary: U.S. securities regulators are drawing back the curtain on foreign companies seeking U.S. stock listings.

headline: Crude Settles Below $99
summary: Crude-oil futures slumped, retreating from gains posted earlier in the week, on a weaker euro and hope for easing tensions between Iran and the West.

headline: Euro Pares Gain on Dollar
summary: The dollar declined against the euro for the week as traders adjusted positions in expectation of some kind of resolution between Greece and its bondholders.

headline: TMX Offer Deadline to Be Extended
summary: A group of Canadian financial institutions is expected to extend its offer for TMX Group beyond the Jan. 31 deadline while the two sides continue to seek approval for the deal from Canadian regulators.

headline: Colombia Targets Inflation as Economy Booms
summary: The central bank president says in an interview he aims to rein in inflation this year even as the nation's booming, oil-led economy fuels consumer demand and higher prices.

headline: Silver Hits Six-Week High
summary: Silver futures surged 3.8% to their highest level in six weeks, as hopes for steady demand for the precious metal replaced the economic gloom that dragged prices lower last month.

headline: Quick Turnaround on AIG Bonds
summary: Credit Suisse said it has already placed with investors a "significant portion" of the billions of dollars of residential mortgage-backed securities it bought from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: My Super PAC Is Driving Me CRAZY
summary: I just don't know how to stop him. This week, in Reply to All.

headline: New Zealand Police Arrest MegaUpload Founder
summary: New Zealand police swooped on MegaUpload's founder Kim Dotcom's home as guests arrived at a home on the outskirts of New Zealand's largest city Auckland to celebrate his birthday.

headline: Dollar Costs Hit 5-Month Low
summary: The cost of accessing dollars in the money market fell to its lowest level in more than five months, in a sign that measures taken by global central banks to alleviate interbank tensions are bearing fruit.

headline: Euro Not in Doubt, Says E.U. Markets Chief
summary: "It's not a crisis of the euro," European Union Financial Markets Commissioner Michel Barnier said. "It's a case of euro-zone economies being in difficulty." He also called for more transparency on how ratings firms decide sovereign-debt ratings.

headline: U.S. to Appeal Tuna Ruling
summary: The U.S. said it would appeal a World Trade Organization decision that favored Mexico in a long-running dispute over "dolphin-safe" labeling for tuna.

headline: Santorum Shines
summary: Rick Santorum brings his A-game to Thursday night's Republican presidential debate.

headline: Schlumberger's Earnings Climb 36%
summary: Schlumberger's fourth-quarter earnings rose 36% as the oil-field-services company's revenue rose in North America.

headline: European Stocks Snap 4-Day Winning Streak
summary: Investors took a breather and most European stock markets edged lower, snapping a four-session run of gains.

headline: Greece Nears Debt Deal
summary: Greece and its private creditors were nearing an agreement on a deal to write down 50% of the face value of the country's debt by swapping existing bonds for new bonds with longer maturities and lower interest rates.

headline: Exxon Mobil, JPMorgan Chase: Money Flow Leaders (XOM, JPM)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Shifting Ship Hampers Rescue Effort in Italy
summary: Rescue operations at the site of the shipwrecked Costa Concordia were suspended as the vessel continued shifting in shallow waters near the island of Giglio.

headline: Fifth Third, SunTrust Show Credit Strength as Profits Fall
summary: Fifth Third Bancorp and SunTrust Banks both reported lower fourth-quarter earnings but, like many other U.S. banks, saw credit costs decline.

headline: Shell Targets Offshore Nova Scotia
summary: Shell said it will spend nearly $1 billion on deep-water oil exploration off the coast of Nova Scotia.

headline: TSE Keeps Olympus Listed, Imposes Fine
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange said it will keep shares of Olympus listed, while slapping a $130,000 fine on the maker of cameras and medical imaging equipment for falsifying financial documents to conceal losses.

headline: Exporters, Banks Lift Asian Stocks
summary: Asian stocks climbed, led by financial stocks and exporters. The Nikkei Stock Average rose 1.5%, and the Hang Seng index headed into the Lunar New Year break with its first close above 20000 in more than 10 weeks.

headline: Ukraine Seeks 'Compromise' With IMF
summary: Ukraine's Finance Minister Valeriy Khoroshkovskiy said he would try to find a "compromise" with the International Monetary Fund to restart much-needed lending, but offered no assurances that Ukraine's government would raise gas prices for households.

headline: Reliance Profit Drops 14%
summary: Reliance Industries reported its first decline in quarterly net profit in more than two years and said it will spend up to 104.40 billion rupees ($2.07 billion) to buy back shares, as it seeks to utilize its huge cash pile and support its battered stock.

headline: Capital One Profit Slides 42%
summary: Capital One's fourth-quarter profit fell 42% as the card-issuer-turned bank reported higher provisions for losses on loans. Shares slid as the results fell short of expectations.

headline: Jet Airways Posts $20 Million Loss
summary: Jet Airways posted its third straight quarterly net loss, though it was smaller than expected as the carrier benefited from a sale and leaseback of planes, a property deal and foreign-exchange gains.

headline: Italy Banks, Union Seal Labor Deal
summary: Italy's banks and the union representing employees in the sector have agreed a new labor contract that will allow bank branches to remain open in the evening and will lead to a new round of hiring.

headline: KBC to Sell Polish Unit
summary: Belgian bank KBC Group has agreed to sell its Polish insurance unit Warta to Germany's Talanx International for €770 million.

headline: U.K. Retail Sales Rise
summary: U.K. retail sales volume rose in December, despite the slowing economy, boosted by record sales of clothing and footwear and mild winter weather, official data showed.

summary: He knows he can't win, but he wants to use his delegates to hold the Republican Party hostage to his views on national security and presidential power.

headline: Vodafone to Invest Further in India
summary: Vodafone plans to invest further in India after the nation's Supreme Court ruled that the mobile giant doesn't have to pay a $2.2 billion tax bill on its 2007 purchase of a majority stake in Indian mobile operator Hutchison Essar, Chief Executive Vittorio Colao said.

headline: Slower Manufacturing Continues in China
summary: A preliminary gauge of Chinese manufacturing activity rose marginally in January, but the index has been in contractionary territory for three months, signaling extended difficulties for the nation's manufacturers.

summary: Ever since Margaret Thatcher opened the U.K. economy to foreign investment, Asian money has periodically poured in and now another wave could be on its way as both China and Japan look for safe places to put funds.

headline: Indian Shares End at Over Six-Week High
summary: Indian shares ended at their highest level in more than six weeks Friday, with bank shares leading the gains and with support from positive Asian markets.

headline: German Data Point to Inflation Drop
summary: German factory prices in December fell on a monthly basis and grew far more slowly on the year than expected, confirming expectations that consumer price inflation is set to fall.

headline: Europe Risks Negative Feedback Loop on Oil

headline: Ikea Gains Market Share; Profit Rises
summary: Ikea posted a rise in annual net profit, gaining market share despite a challenging retail environment, and said it plans to double its investment in the current fiscal year.

headline: Mongolia Aims for Tavan Tolgoi IPO by June

headline: Wipro Profit Rises 10%

summary: The Nehru jacket, always in fashion with Indian politicians, periodically experiences a spike in its pop culture ratings too. In pictures.

headline: CIC Buys Stake in U.K. Utility

summary: The top business leaders in Asia making headlines last week in select global and regional media. Powered by Dow Jones Factiva and edited for relevance and clarity.

headline: Hero MotoCorp to Raise Output

headline: British Class System And White Feathers

headline: AT&T Data Pricing Risks Defections

summary: Long a citadel of consistency, the Giants' offensive line has been anything but this year, with bodies shuffled in, out and along the line. The stalwart in making things work is line coach Pat Flaherty—and his weekly tests.

summary: The operator of the Costa Concordia suspended its captain as investigators scrutinized his final maneuvers and reports emerged that he enjoyed a pre-wreck meal and wine.

summary: With twin entrances, the home of two Massachusetts doctors celebrates its historical origins as two side-by-side duplexes.

summary: Penn State's trustees, facing mounting criticism from alumni over their handling of a sex-abuse scandal, tried to shift blame to the school's former president, Graham Spanier.

summary: Japanese trade and industry minister Yukio Edano said Japan may have no nuclear reactors operating during the peak power demand season in summer, a worrying scenario that could hit domestic production.

summary: Yale ended Trinity's 14-year winning streak in men's squash, but streak snappers seldom go on to win championships.

summary: Plus, "How I Learned to Drive" with Elizabeth Reaser; more Duncan Phyfe in New York.

summary: Jana Partners disclosed a 5.5% stake in Marathon Petroleum, making the hedge fund the refiner's biggest shareholder.

summary: The twin entrances of this 3,000-square-foot, brick-and-clapboard home in Brookline, Mass., are a nod to its origins as two duplexes built as servants' quarters for a nearby estate.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Asra Nomani on Rick Perry, her former colleague Danny Pearl, and the U.S. Marines who urinated on Taliban corpses.

headline: Food Stamp Nation
summary: Gingrich highlights a national disgrace. White House shrugs.

summary: Hedge-fund investors yanked more money from the industry than they added during the final months of 2011, data released Thursday showed.

headline: Bill McCollum: Gingrich Can Repeal ObamaCare
summary: Unlike Mitt Romney, who is burdened by his continued defense of RomneyCare, Newt can fully take on the president.

headline: 'Declaration of War': Snubbed by the Oscars, Loved by the French
summary: "Declaration of War," opening in the U.S. on Jan. 27, is the latest film that attempts to explore the humorous aspects of one of the least funny circumstances known to man: the illness or death of a loved one.

headline: Ski Resorts Call On Higher Authorities to Save Season
summary: Some resorts are dealing with lack of snow in unconventional ways. Vail Resorts has turned to Eddie Box Jr., a member of the Southern Ute Indian Tribe, to perform a snow dance.

headline: Gas Prices Could Rise With Exports
summary: Increased exports of U.S. natural gas could drive up domestic gas prices as much as 54% in 2018, federal officials said, in a projection that could complicate efforts by more than a half-dozen companies hoping to spend billions of dollars on new export terminals.

headline: Ban on Shark Fin Soup Advances Through Asia
summary: A swell of opposition against shark fin soup gained backing from the luxury Shangri-La Hotel chain just days before Chinese New Year.

headline: Argentina Could Halt Capital Flight Easily
summary: Mary Anastasia O'Grady's "Argentina's Capital Flight" (Americas, Jan. 9) highlights fragilities associated with "hot money" outflows. Capital is already leaving Argentina at half the rate experienced during the depths of the Peso Crisis.

headline: Retiree Imbalance Underlies Filing
summary: Kodak, which has twice as many retirees drawing benefits in the U.S. as it has active employees world-wide, hopes to scale back what it owes retirees during its stay in bankruptcy court.

headline: Probation Pays Bills for Prosecutors
summary: As district attorneys nationwide try to cope with shrinking state budgets, Oklahoma prosecutors have seized on a novel—and increasingly controversial—money raiser: running their own probation programs.

headline: Burgundy 2010: Domaines to Watch
summary: Broadly, 2010 is a great vintage in Burgundy, with beautifully ripe reds, concentrated whites and the necessary acid levels to enable these wines to age. Here, in no particular order, is a snapshot of the specific producers whose wines  stood out.

headline: The Edge of Hopelessness
summary: The story of a fatherless family, teetering on the edge of abject poverty, dominated by an unhappy mother whose soul has been crushed by the struggle for survival. You've heard it all before? Maybe—but not like this.

headline: Greece Near Deal on Debt
summary: Greece and its private-sector creditors appeared to be closing in on a debt-restructuring deal, raising hopes it would pave the way for another bailout.

headline: Private Properties
summary: Aerosmith's Steven Tyler pays $4.8 million for a pentagonal home in Hawaii. Also, Hollywood producer Roger Birnbaum relists a house in Beverly Hills, Calif., and Bill Pulte lists a Florida penthouse apartment for $6.5 million.

headline: Companies Ratchet Up Borrowing
summary: Companies have sold $44.2 billion of bonds this year, the highest on record for the time period, according to Dealogic.

headline: Can Bankruptcy Filing Save Kodak?
summary: Eastman Kodak hopes to slash what it owes retirees and force much bigger technology companies to pay to use its patents during its journey through bankruptcy court.

headline: Fewer Debaters, Plenty of Heat

summary: South Carolina's 9.9% unemployment rate is one of the nation's highest because of towns like Dillon on the North Carolina border.

summary: Philip Falcone, one of Wall Street's most famous distressed-debt investors, has received a dose of his own medicine from a veteran, Carl Icahn.

summary: David Makol is an FBI agent who specializes in "flipping" people, or persuading them to gather evidence against their friends. He has played a key role in the sweeping insider-trading probe that has shaken Wall Street.

headline: BofA Swings to Profit
summary: Bank of America closed out a turbulent 2011 with better-than-expected revenue in the final three months of the year. The lender doesn't plan to raise its dividend.

headline: Investment in Indonesia Soars
summary: Foreign direct investment in Indonesia soared more than 20% last year and is expected to continue growing after Moody's and Fitch both raised the country's rating to investment grade for the first time in 14 years.

headline: The MetLife Lesson
summary: Why 4,300 people are suddenly out of a job.

headline: Can Citizen Journalists Add More Value Than Pros?
summary: Peter Funt's recommendation to news organizations, particularly newspapers, is that they bolster their staff of professionals rather than cut costs and rely on amateurs, "citizen journalists," to supply much of their content ("Big Media's Latest Mistake," op-ed, Jan 13).

headline: What to Buy Right Now
summary: Out-of-season clothes often look better, more original and fresher than in-season styles and, if you choose wisely, they can liven up your winter look.

headline: Morgan Stanley Looks Ahead

headline: Air Force Is Off Base on Dismissals
summary: Regarding the Air Force's letter of Jan. 6 defending its terminations of 157 Officers on the eve of their retirement and responding to our "The Air Force Grounds Its Officers" (op-ed, Dec. 28): First, the terminations are illegal.

headline: Strong Emotions, Delivered by Stealth
summary: Novelist Ben Marcus ("The Flame Alphabet") writes the Word Craft column about literature as 'a delivery system for feeling.'

summary: Three big lenders in key euro-zone economies have been hit by a fresh wave of problems, just months after issuing billions of euros of new stock.

summary: Obama rejects the Keystone XL pipeline and blames Congress.

summary: Who's writing classical music these days that's accessible enough to satisfy lay listeners, yet serious enough to impress trained musicians? Morten Lauridsen, that's who.

summary: A look at the soundtrack of the 2012 Republican presidential primary campaign.

summary: The slide marked the eighth consecutive session of lower prices, triggered by an unusually warm winter that has damped demand.

headline: TV on DVD
summary: New releases of past television series include "Kojak: The Complete Movie Collection."

headline: BofA Takes Capital Lessons to Heart
summary: Brian Moynihan started 2011 thinking Bank of America was strong enough to return capital to shareholders. Nowadays, the chief executive is singing a cautious tune.
